text: In this lesson, we're going to take a look at parent materials and instance materials and how to add new features to get your material to be a bit more robust. So let's get started. So one of the things I want to emphasize is make sure that you work from a parent material and you make and always get in the habit of making instance materials from those parent materials and then apply those instance materials to your objects. The reason why you want to do that is you can actually control a set of parent materials where one handles translucency, another one handles flesh, another one handles hard surface organic, another one non-organic. You can actually categorize things in such a way and make instance materials from those parent materials to have quick control over your environment without having to recompile your shader. So this is a very optimized ideal way to work in Unreal to get changes quickly done and to be able to swap out textures. As you can see here in the instance material, we have quick access to these and we can also control variables. Let's briefly take a look in Unreal at what I have set up for you. So in Unreal, we have a sample material. This one's just a little shadier than probably what you have in your scene. Don't worry about it. It's still the same thing. And this is concerning our first topic. Now I'm going to double click on that material and we can see that we have full control of this material. And you will have several sliders as we can swap out also the texture. You'll notice down below we have a metallic switch. Now yours is probably off by default, but with it on, you'll notice at the top we actually have a metalness area and I just loaded a simple blank white texture. In the parent material, these can be any textures because in the instance as we're in here, I can swap them out at any time. So if we turn this off, you'll notice now we have the ability to control our base material via a slider. And that'll control our intensity outside of a texture. Let's move that back to default. And if we turn that back on metallic, you'll now see the texture populate. And that's what we're going to build. We're going to build this in Unreal. And this is what you call a static switch parameter. It makes it a lot easier for your material, especially if you don't want to actually use that 4K material for an object in the distance. You can turn some of these off. Now there are some things in Unreal that automatically do some of this for you. That's for more of the advanced classes. And we're not going to get into it here. So let's go ahead and start building the static switch parameter. I'm also going to point out to you a few other ways you can build nodes to make your material a little bit more stronger in the use and function and to just make it more robust. And then we're going to take a look at that UVs up close. So here in Unreal, I'm going to move this out of the way for now. And we're going to go and make our own material. And so if I connect to this, it's going to lump things in such a way and understand that I'm using this for UVs. I'm going to go ahead and I'm going to keep my finger the S key. And I'm going to connect that into the B channel and UV coordinates and connect it into the A channel. Set this to one to make sure that my tiling is on. Next, this is a micro setup here or I should say macro, what's controlling the whole set. What I want now is to have a little bit more of a micro setup where I'm controlling things on the U and the V. So I'm keeping my finger on the S key. This is going to be my offset U. I can duplicate that, control D. That's a key for that. And I can make this offset V. I want to make sure that both of these are on. So make sure the one is on for each. There we go. But to be able to be able to do to to get this to work correctly, I should say, to be able to be able to do this, we want to use a thing called a append vector. So I'm going to type in append vector. What this does, it allows us to be able to actually have a secondary control. And we can pipe this into an add or multiply. So I can grab this UV offset, plug it into the A channel, grab this offset here and plug it into the B channel. And now if I want, I can choose, let me hit the A key, A and left click and add. Hit my finger, the M key and left click or multiply. Now, the difference between these, if I did add things would shuffle and stay pretty linear, straightforward with no size changes. And I'd have to connect this here and have to connect this here. Or if I want, I can do multiply and I prefer multiply because it scales it a little bit and can maybe hide some of the imperfections for the texture. So I can do that. With those plugged in, we're going to hit, make sure that you hit save. I just hit apply. And then now we look at our instance and you'll see we have UVs all ready to go. Now, again, each one of these has a different UV. Again, each one of these should be in a group. I didn't do it because just to save time and we went over in the first class. But you can now see down here the UV, the offset U, the offset V. You'll see it's scaling and then the overall tiling. So again, using that and the multiply or the add can determine how that's going to shuffle. And I can show you really quick. So I go in here and then switch this to an add for both of these and hit apply. We can now go in here and change things. And you'll notice it's a lot linear. There's no stretching going on. Now, it does make it so it repeats more, so it squishes it. But the other way around, multiply has a little bit more of a scale connected to it. Well, that's it with this lesson. We're going to take a look at creating masked materials.
